channel.title: [java.nio and java.io]Common Misconception
channel.description:
When people think of NIO they think of faster faster faster, this is not always the case. One of the big reasons they released the java.nio package is because it basically made it so that sockets were not limited anymore by thread count. stream-based I/O could possibly turn out to be faster in some cases because it doesn't have to poll, then go off to another thread for reading. NIO's purpose was to allow programmers to create more scalable servers, etc. Not to make the fastest server in the world.
well, if you still think nio(channel) is always faster than old i/o(stream) you can run some tests yourself and see the results. also if i am wrong about anything(this goes to frank_, yz85, super_, etc.) feel free to correct me I am never going to deny being wrong(like a stuck-up dumbass).

item.title: [java.nio and java.io]Common Misconception
item.dc:creator: @ry60003333 ry60003333
item.description:
@ry60003333 wrote:

[quote=“tony_, post:9, topic:254692”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=336541.msg2615620#msg2615620 date=1231018223]
there have been benchmarks of io vs nio and nio was faster in almost all cases, iirc
[/quote]
hence why i said not always the case…[/quote]
Yea, having only a few clients connected java.io could be faster. However, most developers who make a server want it to scale. When the client load starts to get big, NIO ends up being faster. It really goes down to how many clients you want the server to be able to serve at the same time.

Read full topic
